awd_titl_txt: Advancing Oceanographic Methane Sensing Through a Partnership Approach
awd_abstract_narration:
The development of new deep-sea chemical sensors will enable an improved understanding of ocean chemistry.  The researchers will develop a new sensor to measure methane within the ocean. This sensor will be designed to be deployable on a range of underwater and surface vehicles.  This sensor will provide the oceanographic community with a new tool for measuring methane across a range of environments from estuaries to the deep sea.

The goal of the project is to develop an oceanographic mid-infrared methane sensor capable of measuring methane throughout the water column. There is a strong demand for sensors to be sensitive enough to characterize water column levels of methane, opening the door for improved understanding of methane dynamics across all ocean environments. Field tests of this sensor will take place on a test cruise to Guaymas Basin using a range of oceanographic platforms.  This research project is a partnership between academia and industry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Through this project, we developed a Quantum cascade laser (QCL)-based absorption spectrometer for measuring methane (CH4). The QCL-based deep ocean methane sensor utilized a novel sensing modality: Real-time Cavity Ringdown Spectroscopy (rtCRDS). We focused on miniaturizing and reducing power to enable the sensor to be integrated onto a range of platforms and operate in a range of environments. During a 2021 research cruise on the R/V Roger Revelle, we field tested the novel sensor using ROV Jason and AUV Sentry. The development of this sensor was developed through a collaboration between academia (scientists and engineers at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution – WHOI) and industry (RingIR – a small business dedicated to the development of highly sensitive trace gas sensors). Our goal in developing an in situ oceanographic methane sensor was to enhance studies of upper ocean methane production, air-sea flux dynamics, seafloor hydrate dissolution, sediment pore water studies and the ability to reliably search for methane plume features. A methane sensor that is small, light, and low power enough to be placed on floats, surface vehicles, and autonomous underwater vehicles will enable global scale measurements of methane throughout the ocean. Our current understanding of biogeochemical processes involving methane as well as its role in atmospheric radiative forcing and climate dynamics will greatly benefit from the development of new deep-sea chemical sensors capable of highly sensitive and precise measurements.
